abstract: Goldman Sachs made a mistake by setting aside 49 percent of revenue in the first half of 2009 for pay for its employees, Breakingviews says.
snippet: Goldman Sachs made a mistake by setting aside 49 percent of revenue in the first half of 2009 for pay for its employees, Breakingviews says.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs doesn’t normally get too much wrong, Breakingviews says. But the investment bank made a mistake by setting aside 49 percent of revenue in the first half of 2009 for pay for its employees. Goldman is the leader of the Wall Street pack, and it has an opportunity to set an example in the current quarter.

abstract: The Bank of America chief executive Brian Moynihan is making his first trip to China this week as the lender pushes to catch up with rivals in the world’s fastest-growing economy, the Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the situation.
snippet: The Bank of America chief executive Brian Moynihan is making his first trip to China this week as the lender pushes to catch up with rivals in the world’s fastest-growing economy, the Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the s...
lead_paragraph: The Bank of America chief executive Brian Moynihan is making his first trip to China this week as the lender pushes to catch up with rivals in the world’s fastest-growing economy, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the situation.

headline.main: Moynihan Said to Plan First Trip to China

abstract: Affiliated Media, the publisher of 54 newspapers that include The San Jose Mercury News, said on Monday that it has exited bankruptcy protection, The Associated Press reports.
snippet: Affiliated Media, the publisher of 54 newspapers that include The San Jose Mercury News, said on Monday that it has exited bankruptcy protection, The Associated Press reports.
lead_paragraph: Affiliated Media, the publisher of 54 newspapers including The San Jose Mercury News, said on Monday that it had exited bankruptcy protection, The Associated Press reports.

abstract: President Obama’s proposal for a direct tax on banks to pay for future bailouts is gathering momentum in Europe, with Germany set to move ahead with its own levy and Britain expected to endorse a similar measure ahead of the Group of 20 meeting next month.
snippet: President Obama’s proposal for a direct tax on banks to pay for future bailouts is gathering momentum in Europe, with Germany set to move ahead with its own levy and Britain expected to endorse a similar measure ahead of the Group of 20 meeting ne...
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s proposal for a direct tax on banks to pay for future bailouts is gathering momentum in Europe, with Germany set to move ahead with its own levy and Britain expected to endorse a similar measure ahead of the Group of 20 meeting next month, The New York Times’s Matthew Saltmarsh reports from Paris.

headline.main: Bank Bailout Tax Gains Support in Europe
